title: 109_hr1598
content: The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" improves veterans' benefits for former prisoners of war. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" amends section 1112 of title 38, United States Code, by repealing the minimum period of internment for presumption of service connection for certain diseases. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" amends section 1112 of title 38, United States Code by adding new diseases presumed to be service connected, including heart disease, stroke, diabetes (type 2), and osteoporosis. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" adds diabetes (type 2) and osteoporosis to the list of diseases presumed to be service-connected under section 1112 of title 38, United States Code. The Secretary can determine additional diseases warranting a presumption of service connection through regulations. The Secretary can establish a presumption of service connection for diseases associated with being a prisoner of war based on medical evidence. Recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War are considered in making these determinations. The Secretary can establish a presumption of service connection for diseases associated with being a prisoner of war based on medical evidence, including recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War. When evaluating studies for these determinations, the Secretary considers statistical significance, replicability, and peer review. An association between a disease and being a prisoner of war is considered positive if the evidence outweighs any credible evidence against it. The Secretary can establish a presumption of service connection for diseases associated with being a prisoner of war based on medical evidence. If the Advisory Committee recommends a presumption for a disease, the Secretary will determine if it is warranted and issue proposed regulations if so. The Secretary can establish a presumption of service connection for diseases associated with being a prisoner of war based on medical evidence. If the Secretary determines that a presumption of service connection is not warranted, they must publish a notice in the Federal Register within 60 days, explaining the scientific basis for the determination. If the disease is already included in regulations for a presumption of service connection, proposed regulations removing the presumption must be issued within 60 days of the notice. The Secretary shall issue proposed regulations removing the presumption for the disease within 90 days. Final regulations must be issued within 90 days of the proposed regulations. Veterans awarded compensation based on the presumption before the removal shall continue to receive compensation. The Secretary will remove the presumption for a disease within 90 days and issue final regulations within the same timeframe. Veterans receiving compensation based on the presumption will continue to receive it. Survivors of veterans awarded compensation for the disease will also continue to receive benefits. The Secretary will consult with the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War for this subsection. The title, as amended, now includes provisions for diseases prescribed under subsection (d) after those specified in paragraph (2).
